Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Versatile High Energy Resolution Ion Nanosope for Nanoscale Ion Spectroscopy, Ion-based Materials Fabrication and Ion Milling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical abstract:

The development of a new research instrument for nanoscale elemental analysis and materials modification using scattering of noble gas ions creates opportunities for materials science unachievable to date. Intellectual challenges include the creation of the tool, understanding energetic ion-solid interactions with a nano-beam, and applications, both in materials analysis and materials modification. Our project integrates two recent technological developments: Focused nanoscale ion beams available as the Zeiss ORION® He microscope and picosecond timing electronics with high throughput by Ionwerks®. Analysis applications include the first ion beam interrogation of individual nanostructures and determinations of lateral film uniformity. The instrument will also be used for materials modifications such as graphene based counters for single molecule analysis, development of qubit based superconducting junctions for quantum computing and studies of the behavior of defects within nano-structured materials. Also included is the development of nanoscale Ne beams for materials modification and sample preparation, an entirely new ion beam capability. Such beams may be used for ion milling on the nm scale, semiconductor amorphization and implantation with nm precision, spatial control of 'single ion upsets' in electronic devices, new tests of inter-granular defects for fusion applications and the creation of new materials from ion-carved graphene and other two dimensional materials.

Non-technical abstract:

Nanoscale materials have an enormous impact on basic and applied science. Unanticipated phenomena and functionalities are being discovered and exploited commercially at an ever increasing pace. New experimental tools are therefore needed to reliably perform materials characterization and modification at the same level. This project introduces a significant advance through the development of a versatile ion beam facility for true nano-scale ion spectroscopy, ion beam materials modification and ion beam milling. The project integrates new ion beam technologies to allow analysis of individual nano-particles as well as materials modification of nanostructures and ion sculpting and milling with unprecedented spatial control, involving the development of a new, heavy ion nano-beam. This represents a leap in ion beam oriented materials science. New science and technology is anticipated such as the investigation of the ligand binding of gold nanoparticles used in cancer drug delivery, the creation of nanometer orifices to explore DNA sequencing and the formation of quantum structures for advanced computing and communications.
The direct and visually oriented nature of the information from this instrument will illustrate the excitement of materials science to students ranging from middle school to advanced graduate students through a well developed local infrastructure. As Rutgers has an extraordinarily diverse student body, the project will be particularly useful in attracting underrepresented groups. The instrument will provide excellent opportunities for hands-on experience in the development and use of sophisticated scientific equipment for undergraduate students and enrich the graduate curriculum. The general public will be involved through open houses and lectures. As a 'one of a kind' instrument this instrument will attract world leaders in the diverse fields addressed by nano-materials. Together with other recent NSF awarded instrumentation, this instrument will establish Rutgers as a national center for nano-scale microscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to acquire a Helium Ion Microscope (HIM) and to modify it to allow for chemical (atomic) identification of the atoms involved.

The HIM is a new type of microscope that allows the imaging of scientifically interesting surfaces with sub-nanometer lateral resolution. It uses a focused He ion beam incident on the sample, where it produces secondary electrons. The number of these electrons depends on the local structure and atomic composition of  the surface. Measurement of the electron intensity as a function of position reveals the image.. Among the advantages of the HIM, especially for our applications, is that it can image non-conducting surfaces with excellent resolution. The HIM is a commercial instrument. The only supplier is Zeiss in Peabody, Mass. Our HIM has allowed us to study a large number of cross-disciplinary issues; some highlighted below.

Corals and Global Warming: Global warming and a rapid rise in ocean acidity a quarter of the world's coral species may go extinct by 2050. The mechanisms used by these organisms to form their skeletons is important in order to assess their survivability..   Two opposing models exist: i) a process based on calcifying fluid chemistry vs ii) a biologically controlled process mediated by specific skeletal organic molecules. In combination of techniques, our collaboration has shown that the mineral precipitation is driven by the latter model. Randomly arranged, amorphous particles are initially deposited in microenvironments enriched in organic material; they further aggregate and form ordered structures following crystal growth. This suggests that such corals will maintain the ability to precipitate carbonates in coming centuries. A characteristic image of the coral is shown in Fig 1. Note the long fiber-like structures. The coral samples are strongly insulating and the HIM capability to image non-conducting samples without an overlayer was crucial. This project was  in collaboration with P. Falkowski in the Department of Marine and Coastal Sciences at Rutgers and others. A paper has been accepted for publication in Science.

Recovery of Muscle Function: As organisms age, muscle function deteriorates. Our collaborators have developed a series of drugs that promise to stop or even reverse this process. Our HIM images have played an important role in visualizing this process.  HIM samples included tissues of  kidneys of young rats (left picture below, little muscle damage), rats with deliberately damaged kidney muscles (center picture) and damaged kidneys that have been treated with the drug (right picture) (Fig. 2). Our images show dramatically the restoration of muscle function after drug treatment. Note the fingerlike intersecting structures in the left picture, how they are transformed to swollen, poorly organized structures at center, and finally restored to a remarkable degree at right. These very direct and convincing images give important information about the efficacy of the drugs. These drugs are now being tested in dogs in order to assess their extension of the lives of domestic animals. Further, use on humans is being considered. This project was done in under the direction of Dr. H. H. Szeto and her colleagues at the Department of Pharmacology at the Weill-Cornell Medical College in New York City.  A paper has been published in the Journal of the American Society of Nephrology. 

Elemental Identification: A HIM-TOF (time of flight) system has been constructed and successfully tested. The energy of back scattered He ions is determined which, in turn, is a function of the elemental mass of the sample. The ToF scheme employs a fast electron detector as the “start” pulse and a large ion detector placed 13 cm from the sample to generate the “stop” signal. The measured transit time, of order 50-100 nanoseconds, yields the velocity and energy of the backscattered He ion. Shown in Fig. 3 are  results from a thin (1 nm) gold film on top of a thicker (5 nm) Ni film on a sapphire substrate. The Ni and Au peaks are well separated and their widths reflect the differences in the thicknesses. During the past year, we have spent very significant time constructing unique software that handles the data collection. This was crucial to drastically improve the signal-to-noise ratio. This enhanced capability provides an entirely new way to investigate nanostructures with elemental specificity. A paper describing our approach is under preparation. This project was done in collaboration with A. Schulz at Ionwerks Inc. in Houston, TX and others.

To conclude: The projects above show a strongly interdisciplinary approach with collaborators from several different disciplines, some far from our own field. There are also ongoing projects focused on modern inorganic materials such as patterning of high temperature superconductors to form tunnel junctions and modification of two-dimensional materials such as MoS2. The growing capabilities of the instrument are becoming widely recognized and a large “user group” is being formed.
